image.altText: A composite image of Eric Abetz, Craig Garland, Jacqui Lambie and John Tucker.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian elections are complex. But like all polling days, they come down to a series of micro-battles. So which candidates are crucial in determining majority or minority rule?

title.children: Abetz's return? Tucker's revenge? Five battles to watch on election night in Tasmania

image.altText: the exterior of a white apartment building

props.synopsis: One of the country's most high-profile strata management firms has been "preying on people's ignorance" to hit apartment owners with exorbitant fees, ABC Investigations finds.

title.children: Strata firm voted 'company of the year' caught charging excessive fees to home owners

image.altText: Donald Trump's face pictured against a backdrop of red and white horizonal stripes

props.synopsis: Now he's the Republicans' presumptive presidential nominee, Donald Trump's in full campaign mode, and his comments are proving as divisive as ever. We take a close look at what he's been saying he'll do if he's given another term in the White House.

title.children: 'I am your retribution': This is Trump's vision for America, in his own words

image.altText: A man on the phone.

props.synopsis: Tensions between Sikhs and Hindus were ratcheting up when Samar Kohli received a call from ASIO officers proposing a meeting.

title.children: 'Everyone was freaking out': How ASIO quietly reached out to Australian Sikhs rattled by Canada 'hit'

image.altText: Energy Minister Chris Bowen gives a TV interview.

props.synopsis: Minister for Climate Change and Energy Chris Bowen says the average build time for a nuclear power plant in the United States has been nearly two decades. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check runs the numbers.

title.children: We fact checked Chris Bowen on the average build time of a nuclear plant in the US. Here's what we found

image.altText: Rear view of a silhouetted young businesswoman walking down a dark office corridor to a lit doorway.

props.synopsis: How strict non-disclosure agreements in sexual harassment cases can benefit the organisation and perpetrator instead of the victim.

title.children: Rachel was sexually harassed in her workplace, but she was the one who had to leave her job

image.altText: Michelle Heyman holding hands with another matildas player.

props.synopsis: The Matildas' hopes of winning a historic Olympic gold medal will face an early test after they were drawn alongside two heavyweights in the preliminary rounds for the Paris Games.

title.children: Matildas drawn with US and Germany in tough Paris Olympics group stage

image.altText: Peter Dutton and Anthony Albanese cross paths in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: An unhappy experience with the Voice referendum explains the Albanese government’s reticence to push ahead on religious freedoms. Debates that risk inflaming community tensions are best avoided for now, even if that means failing to deliver on an election promise, writes David Speers.

title.children: A long shadow looms for Albanese, as he waits for a deal with Dutton

image.altText: A submarine at the surface with morning sun on its right flank, the ocean stretches behind it

props.synopsis: Visiting British ministers are expected to strengthen military ties by agreeing to work towards a new agreement, which the United Kingdom has only ever enacted with its NATO partners.

title.children: Australia and UK expected to strengthen military ties ahead of nuclear-powered submarine delivery

image.altText: Handheld baby platypus

props.synopsis: The six-month-old female platypus is the first-known animal of its kind to be born in Australia's oldest national park in more than 50 years, and its arrival comes despite a series of recent pollution scares in local waterways.

title.children: Researchers ‘over the moon’ as miracle puggle is born in Sydney’s Royal National Park

image.altText: Two ladies wearing feathered and formal attire sit in a dimly lit room.

props.synopsis: The Museum of Old and New Art (MONA) likes to make a statement – and its 'ladies-only' lounge does just that. But now it's the subject of an anti-discrimination legal fight, brought by a male visitor.

title.children: 'Escaping the patriarchy', or discrimination against men? The legal fight over a ladies-only lounge

image.altText: A doctor wears a blue gown and gloves in the background. A P2 mask sits in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Shingles cases are on the rise in New South Wales. Some doctors and researchers say COVID might be a contributing factor.

title.children: Health workers are seeing a rise in shingles. COVID might be part of the reason why

image.altText: A woman in a black blazer smiles at the camera in front of a fake 'Tasmanien government' background

props.synopsis: Staff at a media company that produces satirical political videos are warned they could face jail time and a fine over a video that shows Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff's face, as it could be seen as "advertisement".

title.children: 'Honest Government Ad' posted by satirical media company censored following complaint to Tasmanian Electoral Commission

image.altText: A smiling woman in a hat sitting on a bench drinking a beer.

props.synopsis: The Newcastle-based Church of Ubuntu sacked Lainie Chait when she got vaccinated against COVID, but the Fair Work Commission has ruled that her dismissal was "inherently unreasonable".

title.children: Woman wins damages after being sacked by wellness clinic for getting COVID vaccine

image.altText: Louis leans on his mum Kate.

props.synopsis: Britain's health minister says she's asked police to investigate claims staff at the hospital where Kate, Princess of Wales, had surgery in January, attempted to access her private medical records.

title.children: Claims hospital staff tried to access Kate Middleton's private health records referred to police

image.altText: Group of city workers walking on street

props.synopsis: The US Federal Reserve left interest rates on hold at its meeting overnight, with the central bank indicating it's still likely to deliver three rate cuts by the end of the year. Wall Street is trading higher as a result, with the ASX set to follow ahead of the latest employment data being released. Follow live.

title.children: US Federal Reserve keeps rates on hold with three cuts likely this year, local employment data for February ahead

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Energy market operator warns of gas shortages in southern states by 2028
Strata company Netstrata caught charging excessive fees and taking kickbacks

image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Ballarat residents say they want closure for the family of missing mother Samantha Murphy after a fresh search failed to locate her body.

title.children: Community devastated after police fail to find body of missing Ballarat mum Samantha Murphy during latest search

image.altText: A collection of credit cards.

props.synopsis: Australians lost an estimated $2.2 billion to card fraud last year, according to new data released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

title.children: Almost 2 million people were victims of card fraud in 2023 as hardest-hit group identified

image.altText: A photo showing a flooded road with windy trees. The road is impassable.

props.synopsis: Borroloola is facing an imminent, record-breaking flood, emergency services say, with the Australian Defence Force attempting to airlift hundreds of residents out of the community before nightfall.

title.children: Evacuation ordered as 'one-in-100-year' flood predicted following ex-Tropical Cyclone Megan

image.altText: Night time photo of Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: The stakes are again high for the steel town of Whyalla as a billionaire owner who has broken past promises looks to a green future.

title.children: A billionaire's bold plan could save this Australian industry icon but past broken promises have workers nervous

image.altText: Archival vision of former Labor minister Craig Emmerson in a parliamentary courtyard.

props.synopsis: More than a decade since former Labor minister Craig Emerson pulled a cringeworthy stunt singing "no Whyalla wipe-out" residents of the town are feeling cautiously optimistic about its future.

title.children: More than a decade since Craig Emerson sung 'no Whyalla wipe-out', how is the city actually faring?

props.synopsis: Police have clashed with Tibetan and Uyghur activists outside the Chinese embassy where the group was protesting against the visit of Foreign Minister Wang Yi.

title.children: Tibetan activists protest outside Chinese embassy against Foreign Minister Wang Yi's visit

image.altText: A view behind of a student on stage with short brown hair raising her fist in the air, a large crowd is blurred in front of her.

props.synopsis: A study of 1,500 schoolchildren across Australia found students are approaching the prospect of climate change in their futures with "urgency and frustration".

title.children: Australian schoolchildren are asking existential questions about climate change

image.altText: People taking photos of Hong Kong at sunset

props.synopsis: A controversial law has finally passed in Hong Kong. The government says it will keep the city safe, but critics call it the final nail in the coffin. Here's what you should know

title.children: Once a glittering financial hub, Hong Kong is facing a mass exodus. Critics say Article 23 will hasten the city's decline

image.altText: A shipping tanker sits upside down in rough seas with only its red underside visible

props.synopsis: The tanker sent a distress call to the local coastguard before going under, with local authorities continuing to search for some missing crew members.

title.children: Eight people killed after South Korean chemical tanker carrying acrylic acid capsizes off Japan

image.altText: An aerial view of a remote solar farm

props.synopsis: A solar farm with the power to service 90,000 homes has switched on in outback Queensland — powering one of the richest mining regions in the world. Experts say green energy will be key to Australia’s role in filling global shortages of metals and minerals.

title.children: Australia's largest remote solar farm switched on to power outback Queensland mining industry

image.altText: Two men hold up a bowl of shamrocks

props.synopsis: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar announced he is quitting immediately as head of Fine Gael party, and will be replaced as prime minister after a leadership contest.

title.children: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadker resigns in 'surprise' announcement

image.altText: A photo of a retail store in a shopping centre selling vacuum cleaners.

props.synopsis: Vacuum cleaner retail chain Godfreys will close by the end of May, after administrators were unable to find a suitable buyer to purchase the business, which had been struggling in the "challenging economic operating environment".

title.children: Godfreys shuts up shop for good after failing to find a buyer for its 92-year-old business

image.altText: An aerial view of dirt land with roads lined and machines on the edge overlooking water

props.synopsis: An insurgent group claimed responsibility for the attack near the Gwadar port which is known for its strategic links to China.

title.children: Eight militants and two soldiers killed in attack near Pakistan's Gwadar port

image.altText: Prabowo Subianto speaks into a microphone.

props.synopsis: Indonesia's election commission has officially confirmed Prabowo Subianto won last month's election but his challengers are set to take the result to court, alleging fraud and voting irregularities.

title.children: He won more than 96 million votes but court challenges loom for Indonesia's new president

image.altText: Sophie Molineux tosses the ball during a WPL match.

props.synopsis: Australia is considering selecting four spinners against Bangladesh in Dhaka, with Sophie Molineux in line to play her first ODI since 2021.

title.children: Australia weighs up its spinning options ahead of opening Bangladesh ODI

image.altText: A young woman with red hair smiles as she looks into the distance.

props.synopsis: With elections looming across the nation, the focus on housing in Tasmania's poll suggests governments are ready to take more radical steps to deal with our housing crisis.

title.children: 'No deposit' home loans, the end of Airbnb and immense rental protections all on the table in an election that could set the scene for other states

image.altText: A firefighter looking through the front window of a truck at a house engulfed by flames.

props.synopsis: Fire and Rescue New South Wales has recorded more than 60 lithium-ion battery fires in the state so far in 2024.

title.children: Beachside homes evacuated as another suspected lithium-ion battery fire destroys house

image.altText: A graphic of holding hands on a blue background with emojis.

props.synopsis: Experts say it's important young people can identify any unhealthy behaviour in a relationship early on, and address it. So what does a positive relationship look like and what are some of the things to look out for?

title.children: How to have a healthy relationship as a teenager
